segment.source: Create an Authentication Request Rule (Windows 10)
segment.target: Create an Authentication Request Rule (Windows 10)

segment.source: Create an Authentication Request Rule
segment.target: Create an Authentication Request Rule

segment.source: Create an Authentication Request Rule
segment.target: Create an Authentication Request Rule

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: After you have configured IPsec algorithms and authentication methods, you can create the rule that requires the devices on the network to use those protocols and methods before they can communicate.
segment.target: After you have configured IPsec algorithms and authentication methods, you can create the rule that requires the devices on the network to use those protocols and methods before they can communicate.

segment.source: Administrative credentials
segment.target: Administrative credentials

segment.source: To complete this procedure, you must be a member of the Domain Administrators group, or otherwise be delegated permissions to modify the GPOs.
segment.target: To complete this procedure, you must be a member of the Domain Administrators group, or otherwise be delegated permissions to modify the GPOs.

segment.source: To create the authentication request rule
segment.target: To create the authentication request rule

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Management Console to Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Management Console to Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.

segment.source: In the navigation pane, right-click Connection Security Rules, and then click New Rule.
segment.target: In the navigation pane, right-click Connection Security Rules, and then click New Rule.

segment.source: On the Rule Type page, select Isolation, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Rule Type page, select Isolation, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Requirements page, select Request authentication for inbound and outbound connections.
segment.target: On the Requirements page, select Request authentication for inbound and outbound connections.

segment.source: Caution: Do not configure the rule to require inbound authentication until you have confirmed that all of your devices are receiving the correct GPOs, and are successfully negotiating IPsec and authenticating with each other.
segment.target: Caution: Do not configure the rule to require inbound authentication until you have confirmed that all of your devices are receiving the correct GPOs, and are successfully negotiating IPsec and authenticating with each other.

segment.source: Allowing the devices to communicate even when authentication fails prevents any errors in the GPOs or their distribution from breaking communications on your network.
segment.target: Allowing the devices to communicate even when authentication fails prevents any errors in the GPOs or their distribution from breaking communications on your network.

segment.source: On the Authentication Method page, select the authentication option you want to use on your network.
segment.target: On the Authentication Method page, select the authentication option you want to use on your network.

segment.source: To select multiple methods that are tried in order until one succeeds, click Advanced, click Customize, and then click Add to add methods to the list.
segment.target: To select multiple methods that are tried in order until one succeeds, click Advanced, click Customize, and then click Add to add methods to the list.

segment.source: Second authentication methods require Authenticated IP (AuthIP).
segment.target: Second authentication methods require Authenticated IP (AuthIP).

segment.source: Default.
segment.target: Default.

segment.source: Selecting this option tells the device to request authentication by using the method currently defined as the default on the device.
segment.target: Selecting this option tells the device to request authentication by using the method currently defined as the default on the device.

segment.source: This default might have been configured when the operating system was installed or it might have been configured by Group Policy.
segment.target: This default might have been configured when the operating system was installed or it might have been configured by Group Policy.

segment.source: Selecting this option is appropriate when you have configured system-wide settings by using the Configure Authentication Methods procedure.
segment.target: Selecting this option is appropriate when you have configured system-wide settings by using the Configure Authentication Methods procedure.

segment.source: Computer and User (Kerberos V5).
segment.target: Computer and User (Kerberos V5).

segment.source: Selecting this option tells the device to request authentication of both the device and the currently logged-on user by using their domain credentials.
segment.target: Selecting this option tells the device to request authentication of both the device and the currently logged-on user by using their domain credentials.

segment.source: This authentication method works only with other devices that can use AuthIP.
segment.target: This authentication method works only with other devices that can use AuthIP.

segment.source: User-based authentication using Kerberos V5 is not supported by IKE v1.
segment.target: User-based authentication using Kerberos V5 is not supported by IKE v1.

segment.source: Computer (Kerberos V5).
segment.target: Computer (Kerberos V5).

segment.source: Selecting this option tells the device to request authentication of the device by using its domain credentials.
segment.target: Selecting this option tells the device to request authentication of the device by using its domain credentials.

segment.source: This option works with other devices than can use IKE v1, including earlier versions of Windows.
segment.target: This option works with other devices than can use IKE v1, including earlier versions of Windows.

segment.source: Advanced.
segment.target: Advanced.

segment.source: Click Customize to specify a custom combination of authentication methods required for your scenario.
segment.target: Click Customize to specify a custom combination of authentication methods required for your scenario.

segment.source: You can specify both a First authentication method and a Second authentication method.
segment.target: You can specify both a First authentication method and a Second authentication method.

segment.source: The First authentication method can be one of the following:
segment.target: The First authentication method can be one of the following:

segment.source: Computer (Kerberos V5).
segment.target: Computer (Kerberos V5).

segment.source: Selecting this option tells the device to request authentication of the device by using its domain credentials.
segment.target: Selecting this option tells the device to request authentication of the device by using its domain credentials.

segment.source: This option works with other devices than can use IKE v1, including earlier versions of Windows.
segment.target: This option works with other devices than can use IKE v1, including earlier versions of Windows.

segment.source: Computer (NTLMv2).
segment.target: Computer (NTLMv2).

segment.source: Selecting this option tells the device to use and require authentication of the device by using its domain credentials.
segment.target: Selecting this option tells the device to use and require authentication of the device by using its domain credentials.

segment.source: This option works only with other devices that can use AuthIP.
segment.target: This option works only with other devices that can use AuthIP.

segment.source: User-based authentication using Kerberos V5 is not supported by IKE v1.
segment.target: User-based authentication using Kerberos V5 is not supported by IKE v1.

segment.source: Computer certificate from this certification authority (CA).
segment.target: Computer certificate from this certification authority (CA).

segment.source: Selecting this option and entering the identification of a CA tells the device to request authentication by using a certificate that is issued by the specified CA.
segment.target: Selecting this option and entering the identification of a CA tells the device to request authentication by using a certificate that is issued by the specified CA.

segment.source: If you also select Accept only health certificates, then only certificates issued by a NAP server can be used for this rule.
segment.target: If you also select Accept only health certificates, then only certificates issued by a NAP server can be used for this rule.

segment.source: Preshared key (not recommended).
segment.target: Preshared key (not recommended).

segment.source: Selecting this method and entering a pre-shared key tells the device to authenticate by exchanging the pre-shared keys.
segment.target: Selecting this method and entering a pre-shared key tells the device to authenticate by exchanging the pre-shared keys.

segment.source: If the keys match, then the authentication succeeds.
segment.target: If the keys match, then the authentication succeeds.

segment.source: This method is not recommended, and is included for backward compatibility and testing purposes only.
segment.target: This method is not recommended, and is included for backward compatibility and testing purposes only.

segment.source: If you select First authentication is optional, then the connection can succeed even if the authentication attempt specified in this column fails.
segment.target: If you select First authentication is optional, then the connection can succeed even if the authentication attempt specified in this column fails.

segment.source: The Second authentication method can be one of the following:
segment.target: The Second authentication method can be one of the following:

segment.source: User (Kerberos V5).
segment.target: User (Kerberos V5).

segment.source: Selecting this option tells the device to use and require authentication of the currently logged-on user by using his or her domain credentials.
segment.target: Selecting this option tells the device to use and require authentication of the currently logged-on user by using his or her domain credentials.

segment.source: This authentication method works only with other devices that can use AuthIP.
segment.target: This authentication method works only with other devices that can use AuthIP.

segment.source: User-based authentication using Kerberos V5 is not supported by IKE v1.
segment.target: User-based authentication using Kerberos V5 is not supported by IKE v1.

segment.source: User (NTLMv2).
segment.target: User (NTLMv2).

segment.source: Selecting this option tells the device to use and require authentication of the currently logged-on user by using his or her domain credentials, and uses the NTLMv2 protocol instead of Kerberos V5.
segment.target: Selecting this option tells the device to use and require authentication of the currently logged-on user by using his or her domain credentials, and uses the NTLMv2 protocol instead of Kerberos V5.

segment.source: This authentication method works only with other devices that can use AuthIP.
segment.target: This authentication method works only with other devices that can use AuthIP.

segment.source: User-based authentication using NTLMv2 is not supported by IKE v1.
segment.target: User-based authentication using NTLMv2 is not supported by IKE v1.

segment.source: User health certificate from this certification authority (CA).
segment.target: User health certificate from this certification authority (CA).

segment.source: Selecting this option and entering the identification of a CA tells the device to request user-based authentication by using a certificate that is issued by the specified CA.
segment.target: Selecting this option and entering the identification of a CA tells the device to request user-based authentication by using a certificate that is issued by the specified CA.

segment.source: If you also select Enable certificate to account mapping, then the certificate can be associated with a user in Active Directory for purposes of granting or denying access to certain users or user groups.
segment.target: If you also select Enable certificate to account mapping, then the certificate can be associated with a user in Active Directory for purposes of granting or denying access to certain users or user groups.

segment.source: Computer health certificate from this certification authority (CA).
segment.target: Computer health certificate from this certification authority (CA).

segment.source: Selecting this option and entering the identification of a CA tells the device to use and require authentication by using a certificate that is issued by the specified CA.
segment.target: Selecting this option and entering the identification of a CA tells the device to use and require authentication by using a certificate that is issued by the specified CA.

segment.source: If you also select Accept only health certificates, then only certificates issued by a NAP server can be used for this rule.
segment.target: If you also select Accept only health certificates, then only certificates issued by a NAP server can be used for this rule.

segment.source: If you check Second authentication is optional, the connection can succeed even if the authentication attempt specified in this column fails.
segment.target: If you check Second authentication is optional, the connection can succeed even if the authentication attempt specified in this column fails.

segment.source: Important: Make sure that you do not select the boxes to make both first and second authentication optional.
segment.target: Important: Make sure that you do not select the boxes to make both first and second authentication optional.

segment.source: Doing so allows plaintext connections whenever authentication fails.
segment.target: Doing so allows plaintext connections whenever authentication fails.

segment.source: After you have configured the authentication methods, click OK on each dialog box to save your changes and close it, until you return to the Authentication Method page in the wizard.
segment.target: After you have configured the authentication methods, click OK on each dialog box to save your changes and close it, until you return to the Authentication Method page in the wizard.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: On the Profile page, select the check boxes for the network location type profiles to which this rule applies.
segment.target: On the Profile page, select the check boxes for the network location type profiles to which this rule applies.

segment.source: On portable devices, consider clearing the Private and Public boxes to enable the device to communicate without authentication when it is away from the domain network.
segment.target: On portable devices, consider clearing the Private and Public boxes to enable the device to communicate without authentication when it is away from the domain network.

segment.source: On devices that do not move from network to network, consider selecting all of the profiles.
segment.target: On devices that do not move from network to network, consider selecting all of the profiles.

segment.source: Doing so prevents an unexpected switch in the network location type from disabling the rule.
segment.target: Doing so prevents an unexpected switch in the network location type from disabling the rule.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: On the Name page, type a name for the connection security rule and a description, and then click Finish.
segment.target: On the Name page, type a name for the connection security rule and a description, and then click Finish.

segment.source: The new rule appears in the list of connection security rules.
segment.target: The new rule appears in the list of connection security rules.
